title: TomPegden published Marks & Spencer has 200 jobs to fill: Here's how to apply
text:
Comments (0) 
A huge distribution centre in North West Leicestershire needs 200 people to join the team this summer. 
The Marks and Spencer distribution hub, in Castle Donington, hopes to fill the new positions with the help of recruitment agency Blue Arrow. 
The hub, which holds up to 16 million products across 900,000 sq ft of floor space, is one of Europe's biggest state-of-the-art distribution facilities. 
The centre, which dispatches 2.2 million items a week, is key to the firm's e-commerce business. 
Jackie Thompson, an employment partnership leader at Jobcentre Plus, said: "Blue Arrow approached us to help fill the warehouse operative positions as M&S prepares for an uplift in summer sales. 
"This latest account reflects the buoyant nature of the jobs market in logistics. We are also recruiting for DHL and UPS at East Midlands Airport." 
The news comes as employment in the UK remains at a record high – despite one business group predicting the jobless total will rise for the rest of the year. 
Latest figures show the UK employment rate at 74.6 per cent, with 31.84 million people in work – an increase of 312,000 on the year and the joint highest rate since records began in 1971. 
The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said the unemployment rate of 4.7 per cent has not been lower since 1975. 
Over the past year in Leicester city, there has been a 16.5 per cent fall in those claiming jobseeker's allowance and universal credit in the city. 
In March there were 4,035 claimants, compared with 4,830 in March 2016. 
However, claimants were up from the 3,985 in February. 
In the wider county of Leicestershire, the number of claimants rose month on month from 3,390 in February this year to 3,535, though claimants were down by 5.5 per across the past 12 months. 
Roger Matthews, senior operations leader at the city JobCentre Plus, said: "The labour market is still very buoyant. 
"We have 9,044 jobs posted in job centres in Leicester. 
"We are finding it is taking up to four weeks to find a job through our centres." 
Scott Knowles, chief executive at East Midlands Chamber, said: "We make things in the East Midlands and we sell them around the world. The reduced value of sterling has led to something of a boom for many companies and that has helped to keep people in work where there had been predictions of job losses. 
"The flipside of the reduction in value of sterling means there are inflationary pressures and employers will have to factor in those rising costs. 
"Month-on-month claimant count figures are beginning to show a rising trend and we have to be realistic and expect that trend to continue for the rest of this year. 
"What we would like to see is that any fall in employment in the East Midlands happens more slowly than the rest of the country. 
"We urge the Government to do everything it can to encourage continued investment in jobs and infrastructure, sending a message to the world UK plc remains open for business despite Brexit." 
For more information and to apply, call Blue Arrow on 0800 169 2945 .
